Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Jeffrey Kuan is "Probability Theory." The host institution for the fellowship is Columbia University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Ivan Corwin.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project produced seven papers, one of which was written with a graduate student, and another was written with an undergraduate. 

The project examined interacting particle systems from several different perspectives. These particle systems have a wide range of applications, such as modeling an electric current or crystal growth. An understanding of the long-time behavior of the interacting particle system will have a wide range of applications.

By apporaching the problem from several viewpoints, the PI was able to find results that were previously inaccessible. One result involved looking at particles with different masses -- in analogy with the electric current, this can be viewed as a defect in the wire. 

In essence, the result says that to analyze an interacting particle systems with infinitely many particles, the problem can be reduced an interacting particle systems with finitely many particles. These is true regardless of the masses of the particles

The approach involved applying algebraic machinery to the probability models. Some simple examples of this machinery is accessible at an undergradute level. The PI led two undergraduate research programs at Columbia University during the time of the project. He hopes to be able to engage in similar activities in the future.
